elements.title: Commitment Progress Visualization Through Graduated Purple Intensity
elements.problem: The micro-commitment escalation ladder (works-0930-001) requires visual feedback that signals progress without creating pressure. Currently, the guest journey has no visual language for commitment progression. Each step looks the same regardless of how far the guest has invested. Cialdini's commitment research shows that people become more confident AFTER committing ('racetrack effect'), but the platform provides no visual reinforcement of this growing confidence. For Tamycka, who is budget-constrained and cautious, the visual design must make each completed micro-commitment feel like progress toward a goal, not like an obligation being loaded onto her.
elements.solution: Use graduated intensity of the brand purple palette to signal commitment depth across the journey: (1) Browsing state (no commitment): Use the lightest purple tint (--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) as the dominant background. Interactive elements use --text-gray (#6b7280). The visual tone is neutral and low-pressure. (2) Interest state (listing saved, days configured): Introduce --secondary-purple (rgb(109,49,194)) as accent on the configured elements. The saved listing card gets a subtle left border in secondary purple. The day-configuration selector uses --chat-purple (rgb(75,71,206)) for selected days. The visual tone shifts to 'engaged.' (3) Commitment state (proposal submitted): The proposal confirmation uses --primary-purple (#31135D) as the dominant color. The confirmation card has a --gradient-purple-primary background (linear-gradient(135deg, #31135D 0%, #5a2d8f 100%)). The visual tone is 'invested and confident.' (4) Confirmed state (terms accepted): Full --primary-purple header with white text, --shadow-purple-lg glow on the lease card. The visual tone is 'arrived and settled.' This graduated approach uses the existing purple palette to create a visual commitment thermometer that the guest subconsciously reads as progress. No new colors are needed; the existing tokens provide sufficient range from bg-off-white to primary-purple-dark.

evidence.quote: Just after placing a bet, they are much more confident of their horse's chances of winning than they are immediately before laying down that bet.
evidence.insight: Post-commitment confidence should be visually reinforced. The shift from light purple (browsing) to deep purple (committed) mirrors the internal confidence shift Cialdini describes.

evidence.quote: Well, that's all very good to know.
evidence.insight: Tamycka's tone shifts from questioning to satisfied as the call progresses and she accumulates information. The visual design should mirror this emotional arc: from tentative (light) to confident (deep).

evidence.quote: Primary purple (#31135D): Brand color, headings, important UI. bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)): Subtle purple-tinted background.
evidence.insight: The existing token system provides a full gradient from nearly-white purple (off-white) to deep brand purple (#31135D). This range is sufficient to encode commitment depth without introducing new colors.

new_tokens_needed: --commitment-border-width: 3px (left border on saved/committed cards -- thicker than --border-width-thick to signal state change)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. --primary-purple (#31135D) on --bg-white (#ffffff) achieves ~14:1 contrast ratio (exceeds AAA). --secondary-purple (rgb(109,49,194)) on --bg-white achieves ~4.8:1 (meets AA). --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-white achieves ~4.6:1 (meets AA for body text). White text on --primary-purple (#31135D) achieves ~14:1 (exceeds AAA).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Commitment depth maps to purple intensity: deeper purple = deeper commitment. The eye reads deep purple as 'important/settled' and light purple as 'optional/exploratory.' This creates an implicit visual hierarchy where committed elements naturally draw more attention.
elements.brand_alignment: Consistent with Split Lease's purple palette as defined in Style-guide.md. The graduated approach uses existing brand tokens without introducing off-brand colors. The progression from subtle to saturated purple reinforces the brand's identity of sophistication and trust (per Paula Scher's design philosophy: 'Clean, modern interfaces with a distinctive purple palette that conveys trust').

elements.title: Social Proof Badge Typography for Similar-Other Trust Signals
elements.problem: The information architecture elements (communicates-0930-002) define where social proof should appear, but not how it should look. Social proof from similar others ('3 families with children have stayed here') needs a distinct visual treatment that signals credibility without competing with the primary content hierarchy. Cialdini's social proof principle works even when people know the evidence is manufactured (canned laughter still works). But for maximum effectiveness, the visual treatment must signal authenticity: real data, from real people, about this specific listing. The challenge is to make social proof visually distinct (so it registers in the scan) but not decorative (so it signals data, not marketing).
elements.solution: Create a social proof badge system using the DM Sans font family for differentiation from the Inter-based UI content: (1) Badge Container: A compact inline element with --bg-off-white (rgb(252,250,255)) background and 1px --border-color (#e5e7eb) border, using --rounded-pill (20px) for a pill shape. This visually separates social proof from content without using a loud color or shadow. (2) Badge Typography: DM Sans at --text-sm (12px) with --font-weight-medium (500). Using DM Sans (the alternative display font from Style-guide.md) differentiates social proof from UI labels (Inter) and body content (Inter/Helvetica), signaling that this is a different category of information: observed evidence, not platform-generated content. (3) Badge Icon: A small Feather icon (users, heart, check-circle) at --icon-xs (16px) in --text-purple (rgb(82,31,147)) preceding the text. The icon adds visual distinctiveness without adding cognitive load. (4) Badge Data: Numerical data within the badge should use --font-weight-semibold (600) to create emphasis within the compact format: '3 families | 8 avg. weeks.' The bold numbers draw the eye to the evidence while the regular-weight context words provide framing. (5) Placement: Badges should always appear inline with related content (adjacent to listing title, adjacent to safety badge, above submit button), never in a separate section. This follows the communicates-0930-002 principle of placing social proof at the point of uncertainty.

evidence.source: cialdini-commitment-socialproof.txt, Ch. 4 (Canned laughter / Social proof mechanism)
evidence.quote: Experiments have found that the use of canned merriment causes an audience to laugh longer and more often when humorous material is presented and to rate the material as funnier.
evidence.insight: Social proof works even when visually obvious. But authentic-looking proof works better than obviously manufactured proof. The typography choice (DM Sans for evidence vs. Inter for UI) subtly signals 'this is observed data' rather than 'this is marketing copy.'

evidence.quote: a lot of people don't feel the need to do that [trial night]. They're sort of comfortable with other home sharing companies.
evidence.insight: Igor delivers social proof in a conversational, understated tone -- not as a headline, but as a side comment. The badge design should mirror this: visible but not shouting. DM Sans at 12px with a pill shape achieves this understated credibility.
DM Sans is already in the design system but underutilized. Using it for social proof badges gives them a distinct visual voice without introducing a new font family.

typography: DM Sans 12px/600 for numerical data within badges
spacing: --spacing-xs (4px) padding inside badge between icon and text
--spacing-sm (8px) margin between badge and adjacent content

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. --text-purple (rgb(82,31,147)) on --bg-off-white (rgb(252,250,255)) achieves approximately 6.5:1 contrast ratio (exceeds AA). --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-off-white achieves approximately 4.5:1 (meets AA). DM Sans at 12px requires minimum 4.5:1 contrast for AA compliance at small text sizes.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Social proof badges are tertiary elements in the visual hierarchy -- visible during a natural scan but not competing with the primary content (price, safety) or secondary content (photos, amenities). The pill shape and DM Sans font create visual distinction without elevation. They should look like metadata, not headlines.
elements.brand_alignment: Uses the existing DM Sans font family and purple tint system. The pill shape (--rounded-pill) is already established as a badge/label pattern in the Split Lease design system (day badges, status pills). This extends that pattern to a new information category (social proof) without introducing new visual elements.

elements.title: Child-Safety Visual Language for Family-Friendly Listings
elements.problem: The child-safety verification system (works-0930-005) needs a visual language that signals safety and trust to parent guests without deterring non-parent guests. Currently, the platform has no visual differentiation between family-friendly and general listings. For Tamycka, the absence of safety signals is itself a signal of uncertainty ('I have no evidence that this space is safe for my children'). Cialdini's pluralistic ignorance concept applies: if no one is visually signaling safety concern, a cautious parent may assume either that safety is not an issue (unlikely for a parent of a 5-month-old) or that the platform is not designed for families (likely conclusion). The visual system must create an unambiguous safety signal that is scannable in under 2 seconds on both search results and listing pages.
elements.solution: Design a family-friendly verification badge using the existing token system with warm accent colors for differentiation: (1) Badge Design: A compact pill badge using --accent-blue (#4A90E2) as the badge background with --white text. Blue is chosen because it is already in the system, carries associations with safety and trust, and visually differentiates from the purple commitment signals (preventing badge confusion). The badge reads 'Family-Friendly' with a Feather shield icon (feathericons.com: 'shield') at --icon-xs (16px). (2) Search Card Placement: The badge appears in the top-left corner of the listing card, overlaying the photo. This ensures it is visible during a rapid scan of search results. (3) Listing Page Placement: The badge appears adjacent to the listing title, followed by a compact expandable detail line: 'Verified by host + 2 families: Disinfection between guests, outlet covers available, cleaning products secured.' (4) Verification Level Indicators: The badge intensity increases with verification depth: host-declared only (--accent-blue at --opacity-hover 0.8), host + 1 family verified (full --accent-blue), host + 3+ families verified (--accent-blue with a subtle --shadow-sm). This graduated approach echoes the commitment visualization pattern (looks-0930-001) and rewards hosts who accumulate family verification. (5) Typography: Inter at --text-xs (11px) with --font-weight-semibold (600) for the badge text, ensuring readability at small sizes while maintaining compact footprint.

evidence.quote: As long as we're able to disinfect.
evidence.insight: Tamycka's disinfection requirement is visual -- she needs to SEE the safety signal before she can proceed. An invisible safety status ('we guarantee cleanliness in our terms of service') does not resolve her uncertainty. A visible badge does.

evidence.quote: the important thing, just that they understand that there are so like my one, one little guy, he is five months and then my other little guy he's six years.
evidence.insight: The children's ages (5 months, 6 years) span different safety needs. The expandable detail line allows Tamycka to check specifically which safety features are verified without cluttering the scan view.

evidence.quote: each person decides that since nobody is concerned, nothing is wrong. Meanwhile, the danger may be mounting.
evidence.insight: A visible safety badge breaks pluralistic ignorance by explicitly signaling that safety IS a concern that has been addressed. Without the badge, the absence of signal reads as 'no one cares about this' to a worried parent.

spacing: --spacing-md (12px) between badge and expandable detail content
new_tokens_needed: --family-badge-opacity-unverified: 0.8 (for host-declared-only state, where family validation is pending)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. White text on --accent-blue (#4A90E2) achieves approximately 3.1:1 contrast ratio, which does NOT meet AA for small text. Resolution: Use --primary-purple (#31135D) on a light blue background (--bg-info #f0f7ff) as an alternative that achieves 14:1+ contrast. Alternatively, increase badge font size to --text-sm (12px) where 3:1 meets AA for large text/UI components per WCAG 2.1 definition of 'large scale text.'
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The family-friendly badge is a secondary visual element: it should be noticed during the scan but should not dominate the listing card. On search results, it appears as an overlay in a consistent position (top-left). On the listing page, it appears inline with the title. The blue color differentiates it from purple commitment signals, preventing visual confusion between 'this listing is family-safe' and 'you are committed to this listing.'
elements.brand_alignment: Uses existing --accent-blue token, which is already in the design system for secondary accents and links. The shield icon (Feather) follows the icon library policy. The pill shape follows the established badge pattern. The safety signal adds warmth and trust to the brand's purple-dominant palette without introducing off-brand colors. Per Paula Scher's recommendations, the addition of a purposeful non-purple accent (blue for safety) provides 'direction through contrast' within the monochromatic palette.

elements.title: Price Calculator Visual Treatment for Budget-First Guest Scanning
elements.problem: The information architecture (communicates-0930-001) places a live price calculator as the primary element on the listing page. But the visual treatment of price information on the current platform follows standard e-commerce conventions: nightly rate in large text, total in smaller text below. For a budget-first guest like Tamycka, this hierarchy is inverted. She needs the total cost for her configured stay to be the visually dominant number, with the per-night rate as supporting context. Additionally, bulk discount savings must be visually salient -- Tamycka was explicitly told she could get below $75/night for 30+ nights (05:26-05:28). The savings compared to nightly booking should be visually celebrated, not buried in fine print. Cialdini's commitment research suggests that seeing the savings number creates a small commitment to the budget-friendly option, anchoring the guest to the discounted price.
elements.solution: Design a price calculator panel with inverted visual hierarchy that leads with total cost: (1) Total Cost Display: The configured total ('$675 for 10 weeks') displayed in Inter at --text-2xl (28px) with --font-weight-bold (700) in --primary-purple (#31135D). This is the largest and most prominent number on the listing page. (2) Per-Night Rate: Displayed below the total in Inter at --text-md (16px) with --font-weight-medium (500) in --text-gray (#6b7280). This is contextual, not primary. (3) Savings Indicator: If the configured stay qualifies for a bulk discount, show a savings callout: 'You save $180 vs. nightly rates' in Inter at --text-sm (12px) with --font-weight-semibold (600) in --success-green (#4B47CE). The savings line uses the success color (which is purple in the Split Lease system, not green) to signal positive outcome. (4) Calculator Background: The price panel uses --bg-light (#f9fafb) background with --border-color (#e5e7eb) border and --rounded-xl (12px) corners. It is visually contained, creating a 'price zone' that the eye can locate instantly. (5) Live Update Animation: When the guest changes days or duration, the total updates with a subtle --transition-fast (0.1s) fade, drawing attention to the change without jarring the eye. (6) Fee Transparency Line: Below the total, in --text-light-gray (#9ca3af) at --text-xs (11px), show 'Includes all fees' or an expandable breakdown. This prevents the lowball perception by confirming that the displayed total IS the final total.

evidence.quote: for me, it's more a price than it is location
evidence.insight: Price is the primary scanning criterion. The visual design must make the total cost the first and largest element the budget guest's eye hits.

evidence.quote: I think we could get you under $75 a night.
evidence.insight: Tamycka was verbally promised a price target. The savings indicator ('You save $X') visually confirms that the platform delivers on the promise made in the call.

evidence.quote: An advantage is offered that induces a favorable purchase decision; then, sometime after the decision has been made but before the bargain is sealed, the original purchase advantage is deftly removed.
evidence.insight: The 'Includes all fees' line at the bottom of the calculator panel is the visual anti-lowball mechanism. It confirms: the price you see is the price you pay. No deft removal will occur.

spacing: --spacing-sm (8px) between per-night rate and savings indicator
--spacing-lg (16px) between price panel and content below

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. --primary-purple (#31135D) on --bg-light (#f9fafb) achieves approximately 13.5:1 contrast ratio (exceeds AAA). --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-light achieves approximately 4.5:1 (meets AA). --text-light-gray (#9ca3af) on --bg-light achieves approximately 2.5:1 (does NOT meet AA). Resolution: Use --text-gray (#6b7280) for the fee transparency line instead of --text-light-gray, or increase to --text-sm (12px) size.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The total cost is the undisputed visual primary: largest font, boldest weight, deepest color. Per-night rate is secondary context. Savings indicator is tertiary reward signal. Fee transparency is quaternary reassurance. This four-level hierarchy within a single panel creates a complete price story that Tamycka can scan in under 3 seconds.
elements.brand_alignment: Uses the core purple palette for price emphasis (--primary-purple for total, --success-green (which IS purple in Split Lease) for savings). The contained panel with --rounded-xl corners follows the card component pattern from Style-guide.md. The live update animation uses existing --transition-fast timing. No off-brand elements introduced.
